newsitem.title: FRANCE: Bonino attacks farm lobby over BSE.
newsitem.headline: Bonino attacks farm lobby over BSE.

text.p: European Union consumer affairs commissioner Emma Bonino on Thursday attacked the bloc's powerful farmers lobby for overriding consumer interests in the mad cow crisis.
"The market is made up of producers and consumers. Producers currently have far more power. Balance must be restored," Bonino told a European Parliament committee of inquiry in Strasbourg.

The crisis erupted in March when the British government disclosed that humans could catch mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), which has ravaged British herds over the past 10 years.
Bonino, a former Italian member of the parliament's radical group, said that the dominance of agricultural interests was shown in the European Commission.
"We have 41 officials dealing with consumer affairs, compared with more than 1,000 in agriculture," she said, adding: "We don't even have enough people to read all the documents they produce."
The consumer budget amounted to only 19 million Ecus ($24 million), or 0.021 percent of the EU budget, compared with 40 billion Ecus, or nearly 50 percent, for agriculture, she said.
Bonino added that she could not understand why EU product liability rules were optional for agricultural products. Only in Sweden, Finland and Luxembourg were farmers liable for failures.
Veterinary inspection services were too often attached to agriculture ministries, Bonino said. Only in Italy, Austria and Ireland were they part of the public health ministry.
Bonino said she supported EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler's call for an independent agency, on the lines of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.
Belgian socialist Jose Happart welcomed Bonino's comments.
"This breath of fresh air was most welcome after the hypocrisy I detected in others we heard beforehand," he said.
The Parliament, which started its inquiry in September, is due to issue a report in February.
